trans-unit.source: Using SCIM to enable automatic provisioning of users and groups from Azure Active Directory to applications | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Using SCIM to enable automatic provisioning of users and groups from Azure Active Directory to applications | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Azure Active Directory can automatically provision users and groups to any application or identity store that is fronted by a Web service with the interface defined in the SCIM protocol specification
trans-unit.target: Azure Active Directory can automatically provision users and groups to any application or identity store that is fronted by a Web service with the interface defined in the SCIM protocol specification

trans-unit.source: Using SCIM to enable automatic provisioning of users and groups from Azure Active Directory to applications
trans-unit.target: Using SCIM to enable automatic provisioning of users and groups from Azure Active Directory to applications

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: Azure Active Directory can automatically provision users and groups to any application or identity store that is fronted by a Web service with the interface defined in the [SCIM 2.0 protocol specification](https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-scim-api-19).
trans-unit.target: Azure Active Directory can automatically provision users and groups to any application or identity store that is fronted by a Web service with the interface defined in the [SCIM 2.0 protocol specification](https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-scim-api-19).

trans-unit.source: Azure Active Directory can send requests to create, modify and delete assigned users and groups to this Web service, which can then translate those requests into operations upon the target identity store.
trans-unit.target: Azure Active Directory can send requests to create, modify and delete assigned users and groups to this Web service, which can then translate those requests into operations upon the target identity store.

trans-unit.source: Figure: Provisioning from Azure Active Directory to an identity store via a Web service
trans-unit.target: Figure: Provisioning from Azure Active Directory to an identity store via a Web service

trans-unit.source: This capability can be used in conjunction with the “[bring your own app](http://blogs.technet.com/b/ad/archive/2015/06/17/bring-your-own-app-with-azure-ad-self-service-saml-configuration-gt-now-in-preview.aspx)” capability in Azure AD to enable single sign-on and automatic user provisioning for applications that provide or are fronted by a SCIM web service.
trans-unit.target: This capability can be used in conjunction with the “[bring your own app](http://blogs.technet.com/b/ad/archive/2015/06/17/bring-your-own-app-with-azure-ad-self-service-saml-configuration-gt-now-in-preview.aspx)” capability in Azure AD to enable single sign-on and automatic user provisioning for applications that provide or are fronted by a SCIM web service.

trans-unit.source: There are two use cases for SCIM in Azure Active Directory:
trans-unit.target: There are two use cases for SCIM in Azure Active Directory:

trans-unit.source: **Provisioning users and groups to applications that support SCIM** - Applications that support SCIM 2.0 and are capable of accepting an OAuth bearer token from Azure AD will work with Azure AD of the box.
trans-unit.target: **Provisioning users and groups to applications that support SCIM** - Applications that support SCIM 2.0 and are capable of accepting an OAuth bearer token from Azure AD will work with Azure AD of the box.

trans-unit.source: **Build your own provisioning solution for applications that support other API-based provisioning** - For non-SCIM applications, you can create a SCIM endpoint to translate between Azure AD’s SCIM endpoint and whatever API the application supports for user provisioning.
trans-unit.target: **Build your own provisioning solution for applications that support other API-based provisioning** - For non-SCIM applications, you can create a SCIM endpoint to translate between Azure AD’s SCIM endpoint and whatever API the application supports for user provisioning.

trans-unit.source: To aid in the development of a SCIM endpoint, we provide CLI libraries along with code samples that show you how to do provide a SCIM endpoint and translate SCIM messages.
trans-unit.target: To aid in the development of a SCIM endpoint, we provide CLI libraries along with code samples that show you how to do provide a SCIM endpoint and translate SCIM messages.

trans-unit.source: Provisioning Users and Groups To Applications That Support SCIM
trans-unit.target: Provisioning Users and Groups To Applications That Support SCIM

trans-unit.source: Azure Active Directory can be configured to automatically provision assigned users and groups to applications that implement a [System for Cross-domain Identity Management 2 (SCIM)](https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-scim-api-19) Web service and accept OAuth bearer tokens for authentication.
trans-unit.target: Azure Active Directory can be configured to automatically provision assigned users and groups to applications that implement a [System for Cross-domain Identity Management 2 (SCIM)](https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-scim-api-19) Web service and accept OAuth bearer tokens for authentication.

trans-unit.source: Within the SCIM 2.0 specification, applications must meet these requirements:
trans-unit.target: Within the SCIM 2.0 specification, applications must meet these requirements:

trans-unit.source: Supports creating users and/or groups, as per section 3.3 of the SCIM protocol.
trans-unit.target: Supports creating users and/or groups, as per section 3.3 of the SCIM protocol.

trans-unit.source: Supports modifying users and/or groups with patch requests as per section 3.5.2 of the SCIM protocol.
trans-unit.target: Supports modifying users and/or groups with patch requests as per section 3.5.2 of the SCIM protocol.

trans-unit.source: Supports retrieving a known resource as per section 3.4.1 of the SCIM protocol.
trans-unit.target: Supports retrieving a known resource as per section 3.4.1 of the SCIM protocol.

trans-unit.source: Supports querying users and/or groups, as per section 3.4.2 of the SCIM protocol.
trans-unit.target: Supports querying users and/or groups, as per section 3.4.2 of the SCIM protocol.

trans-unit.source: By default, users are queried by externalId and groups are queried by displayName.
trans-unit.target: By default, users are queried by externalId and groups are queried by displayName.

trans-unit.source: Supports querying user by ID and by manager as per section 3.4.2 of the SCIM protocol.
trans-unit.target: Supports querying user by ID and by manager as per section 3.4.2 of the SCIM protocol.

trans-unit.source: Supports querying groups by ID and by member as per section 3.4.2 of the SCIM protocol.
trans-unit.target: Supports querying groups by ID and by member as per section 3.4.2 of the SCIM protocol.

trans-unit.source: Accepts OAuth bearer tokens for authorization as per section 2.1 of the SCIM protocol.
trans-unit.target: Accepts OAuth bearer tokens for authorization as per section 2.1 of the SCIM protocol.

trans-unit.source: Supports using Azure AD as the identity provider for the OAuth token (support for external identity providers coming soon)
trans-unit.target: Supports using Azure AD as the identity provider for the OAuth token (support for external identity providers coming soon)

trans-unit.source: You should check with your application provider, or your application provider's documentation for statements of compatibility with these requirements.
trans-unit.target: You should check with your application provider, or your application provider's documentation for statements of compatibility with these requirements.

trans-unit.source: Getting Started
trans-unit.target: Getting Started

trans-unit.source: Applications that support the SCIM profile described above can be connected to Azure Active Directory using the "custom" app feature in the Azure AD application gallery.
trans-unit.target: Applications that support the SCIM profile described above can be connected to Azure Active Directory using the "custom" app feature in the Azure AD application gallery.

trans-unit.source: Once connected, Azure AD runs a synchronization process every 5 minutes where it queries the application's SCIM endpoint for assigned users and groups, and creates or modifies them according to the assignment details.
trans-unit.target: Once connected, Azure AD runs a synchronization process every 5 minutes where it queries the application's SCIM endpoint for assigned users and groups, and creates or modifies them according to the assignment details.

trans-unit.source: To connect an applicaiton that supports SCIM:
trans-unit.target: To connect an applicaiton that supports SCIM:

trans-unit.source: In a web browser, launch the Azure management portal at https://manage.windowsazure.com.
trans-unit.target: In a web browser, launch the Azure management portal at https://manage.windowsazure.com.

trans-unit.source: Browse to **Active Directory > Directory > [Your Directory] > Applications**, and select **Add > Add an application from the gallery**.
trans-unit.target: Browse to **Active Directory > Directory > [Your Directory] > Applications**, and select **Add > Add an application from the gallery**.

trans-unit.source: Select the **Custom** tab on the left, enter a name for your application, and click the checkmark icon to create an app object.
trans-unit.target: Select the **Custom** tab on the left, enter a name for your application, and click the checkmark icon to create an app object.

trans-unit.source: In the resulting screen, select the second **Configure account provisioning** button.
trans-unit.target: In the resulting screen, select the second **Configure account provisioning** button.

trans-unit.source: In the dialog, enter the URL of the application's SCIM endpoin.
trans-unit.target: In the dialog, enter the URL of the application's SCIM endpoin.

trans-unit.source: Click **Next**, and click on the **Start Test** button to have Azure Active Directory attempt to connect to the SCIM endpoint.
trans-unit.target: Click **Next**, and click on the **Start Test** button to have Azure Active Directory attempt to connect to the SCIM endpoint.

trans-unit.source: If the attempts fail, diagnostic information will be displayed.
trans-unit.target: If the attempts fail, diagnostic information will be displayed.

trans-unit.source: If the attempts to connect to the application succeed, then click **Next** on the remaining screens, and click **Complete** to exit the dialog.
trans-unit.target: If the attempts to connect to the application succeed, then click **Next** on the remaining screens, and click **Complete** to exit the dialog.

trans-unit.source: In the resulting screen, select the third **Assign Accounts** button.
trans-unit.target: In the resulting screen, select the third **Assign Accounts** button.

trans-unit.source: In the resulting Users and Groups section, assign the users or groups you want to provision to the application.
trans-unit.target: In the resulting Users and Groups section, assign the users or groups you want to provision to the application.

trans-unit.source: Once users and groups are assigned, click the **Configure** tab near the top of the screen.
trans-unit.target: Once users and groups are assigned, click the **Configure** tab near the top of the screen.

trans-unit.source: Under **Account Provisioning**, confirm that the Status is set to On.
trans-unit.target: Under **Account Provisioning**, confirm that the Status is set to On.

trans-unit.source: Under **Tools**, click **Restart account provisioning** to kick-start the provisioning process.
trans-unit.target: Under **Tools**, click **Restart account provisioning** to kick-start the provisioning process.

trans-unit.source: Note that 5-10 minutes may elapse before the provisioning process will begin to send requests to the SCIM endpoint.
trans-unit.target: Note that 5-10 minutes may elapse before the provisioning process will begin to send requests to the SCIM endpoint.

trans-unit.source: A summary of connection attempts is provided on the application’s Dashboard tab, and both a report of provisioning activity and any provisioning errors can be downloaded from the directory’s Reports tab.
trans-unit.target: A summary of connection attempts is provided on the application’s Dashboard tab, and both a report of provisioning activity and any provisioning errors can be downloaded from the directory’s Reports tab.

trans-unit.source: Building Your Own Provisioning Solution For Any Application
trans-unit.target: Building Your Own Provisioning Solution For Any Application

trans-unit.source: By creating a SCIM web service that interfaces with Azure Active Directory, you can enable single sign-on and automatic user provisioning for virtually any application that provides a REST or SOAP user provisioning API.
trans-unit.target: By creating a SCIM web service that interfaces with Azure Active Directory, you can enable single sign-on and automatic user provisioning for virtually any application that provides a REST or SOAP user provisioning API.

trans-unit.source: Here’s how it works:
trans-unit.target: Here’s how it works:

trans-unit.source: Azure AD provides a common language infrastructure library named [Microsoft.SystemForCrossDomainIdentityManagement](https://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.SystemForCrossDomainIdentityManagement/).
trans-unit.target: Azure AD provides a common language infrastructure library named [Microsoft.SystemForCrossDomainIdentityManagement](https://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.SystemForCrossDomainIdentityManagement/).

trans-unit.source: System integrators and developers can use this library to create and deploy a SCIM-based web service endpoint capable of connecting Azure AD to any application’s identity store.
trans-unit.target: System integrators and developers can use this library to create and deploy a SCIM-based web service endpoint capable of connecting Azure AD to any application’s identity store.

trans-unit.source: Mappings are implemented in the web service to map the standardized user schema to the user schema and protocol required by the application.
trans-unit.target: Mappings are implemented in the web service to map the standardized user schema to the user schema and protocol required by the application.

trans-unit.source: The endpoint URL is registered in Azure AD as part of a custom application in the application gallery.
trans-unit.target: The endpoint URL is registered in Azure AD as part of a custom application in the application gallery.

trans-unit.source: Users and groups are assigned to this application in Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: Users and groups are assigned to this application in Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: Upon assignment, they are put into a queue to be synchronized to the target application.
trans-unit.target: Upon assignment, they are put into a queue to be synchronized to the target application.

trans-unit.source: The synchronization process handling the queue runs every 5 minutes.
trans-unit.target: The synchronization process handling the queue runs every 5 minutes.

trans-unit.source: Code Samples
trans-unit.target: Code Samples

trans-unit.source: To make this process easier, a set of [code samples](https://github.com/Azure/AzureAD-BYOA-Provisioning-Samples/tree/master) are provided that create a SCIM web service endpoint and demonstrate automatic provisioning.
trans-unit.target: To make this process easier, a set of [code samples](https://github.com/Azure/AzureAD-BYOA-Provisioning-Samples/tree/master) are provided that create a SCIM web service endpoint and demonstrate automatic provisioning.

trans-unit.source: One sample is of a provider that maintains a file with rows of comma-separated values representing users and groups.
trans-unit.target: One sample is of a provider that maintains a file with rows of comma-separated values representing users and groups.

trans-unit.source: The other is of a provider that operates on the Amazon Web Services Identity and Access Management service.
trans-unit.target: The other is of a provider that operates on the Amazon Web Services Identity and Access Management service.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio 2013 or later
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio 2013 or later

trans-unit.source: Azure SDK for .NET
trans-unit.target: Azure SDK for .NET

trans-unit.source: Windows machine that supports the ASP.NET framework 4.5 to be used as the SCIM endpoint.
trans-unit.target: Windows machine that supports the ASP.NET framework 4.5 to be used as the SCIM endpoint.

trans-unit.source: This machine must be accessible from the cloud
trans-unit.target: This machine must be accessible from the cloud

trans-unit.source: An Azure subscription with a trial or licensed version of Azure AD Premium
trans-unit.target: An Azure subscription with a trial or licensed version of Azure AD Premium

trans-unit.source: The Amazon AWS sample requires libraries from the [AWS Toolkit for Visual Studio](http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSToolkitVS/latest/UserGuide/tkv_setup.html).
trans-unit.target: The Amazon AWS sample requires libraries from the [AWS Toolkit for Visual Studio](http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSToolkitVS/latest/UserGuide/tkv_setup.html).

trans-unit.source: See the README file included with the sample for additional details
trans-unit.target: See the README file included with the sample for additional details

trans-unit.source: Getting Started
trans-unit.target: Getting Started

trans-unit.source: The easiest way to implement a SCIM endpoint that can accept provisioning requests from Azure AD is to build and deploy the code sample that outputs the provisioned users to a comma-separated value (CSV) file.
trans-unit.target: The easiest way to implement a SCIM endpoint that can accept provisioning requests from Azure AD is to build and deploy the code sample that outputs the provisioned users to a comma-separated value (CSV) file.

trans-unit.source: To create a sample SCIM endpoint:
trans-unit.target: To create a sample SCIM endpoint:

trans-unit.source: Download the code sample package at [https://github.com/Azure/AzureAD-BYOA-Provisioning-Samples/tree/master](https://github.com/Azure/AzureAD-BYOA-Provisioning-Samples/tree/master)
trans-unit.target: Download the code sample package at [https://github.com/Azure/AzureAD-BYOA-Provisioning-Samples/tree/master](https://github.com/Azure/AzureAD-BYOA-Provisioning-Samples/tree/master)

trans-unit.source: Unzip the package and place it on your Windows machine at a location such as C:\AzureAD-BYOA-Provisioning-Samples\.
trans-unit.target: Unzip the package and place it on your Windows machine at a location such as C:\AzureAD-BYOA-Provisioning-Samples\.

trans-unit.source: In this folder, launch the FileProvisioningAgent solution in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: In this folder, launch the FileProvisioningAgent solution in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: Select **Tools > Library Package Manager > Package Manager Console**, and execute the commands below for the FileProvisioningAgent project to resolve the solution references:
trans-unit.target: Select **Tools > Library Package Manager > Package Manager Console**, and execute the commands below for the FileProvisioningAgent project to resolve the solution references:

trans-unit.source: Install-Package Microsoft.SystemForCrossDomainIdentityManagement
trans-unit.target: Install-Package Microsoft.SystemForCrossDomainIdentityManagement

trans-unit.source: Install-Package Microsoft.IdentityModel.Clients.ActiveDirectory
trans-unit.target: Install-Package Microsoft.IdentityModel.Clients.ActiveDirectory

trans-unit.source: Install-Package Microsoft.Owin.Diagnostics
trans-unit.target: Install-Package Microsoft.Owin.Diagnostics

trans-unit.source: Install-Package Microsoft.Owin.Host.SystemWeb
trans-unit.target: Install-Package Microsoft.Owin.Host.SystemWeb

trans-unit.source: Build the FileProvisioningAgent project.
trans-unit.target: Build the FileProvisioningAgent project.

trans-unit.source: Launch the Command Prompt application in Windows (as an Administrator), and use the **cd** command to change the directory to your **\AzureAD-BYOA-Provisioning-Samples\ProvisioningAgent\bin\Debug** folder.
trans-unit.target: Launch the Command Prompt application in Windows (as an Administrator), and use the **cd** command to change the directory to your **\AzureAD-BYOA-Provisioning-Samples\ProvisioningAgent\bin\Debug** folder.

trans-unit.source: Run the command below, replacing <ip-address> with the IP or domain name of the Windows Machine.
trans-unit.target: Run the command below, replacing <ip-address> with the IP or domain name of the Windows Machine.

trans-unit.source: FileAgnt.exe http://<ip-address>:9000 TargetFile.csv
trans-unit.target: FileAgnt.exe http://<ip-address>:9000 TargetFile.csv

trans-unit.source: In Windows under **Windows Settings > Network & Internet Settings**, select the **Windows Firewall > Advanced Settings**, and create an **Inbound Rule** that allows inbound access to port 9000.
trans-unit.target: In Windows under **Windows Settings > Network & Internet Settings**, select the **Windows Firewall > Advanced Settings**, and create an **Inbound Rule** that allows inbound access to port 9000.

trans-unit.source: If the Windows machine is behind a router, the router will need to be configured to perform Network Access Translation between its port 9000 that is exposed to the internet, and port 9000 on the Windows machine.
trans-unit.target: If the Windows machine is behind a router, the router will need to be configured to perform Network Access Translation between its port 9000 that is exposed to the internet, and port 9000 on the Windows machine.

trans-unit.source: This is required for Azure AD to be able to access this endpoint in the cloud.
trans-unit.target: This is required for Azure AD to be able to access this endpoint in the cloud.

trans-unit.source: To register the sample SCIM endpoint in Azure AD:
trans-unit.target: To register the sample SCIM endpoint in Azure AD:

trans-unit.source: In a web browser, launch the Azure management portal at https://manage.windowsazure.com.
trans-unit.target: In a web browser, launch the Azure management portal at https://manage.windowsazure.com.

trans-unit.source: Browse to **Active Directory > Directory > [Your Directory] > Applications**, and select **Add > Add an application from the gallery**.
trans-unit.target: Browse to **Active Directory > Directory > [Your Directory] > Applications**, and select **Add > Add an application from the gallery**.

trans-unit.source: Select the **Custom** tab on the left, enter a name such as “SCIM Test App”, and click the checkmark icon to create an app object.
trans-unit.target: Select the **Custom** tab on the left, enter a name such as “SCIM Test App”, and click the checkmark icon to create an app object.

trans-unit.source: Note that the application object created is intend to represent the target app you would be provisioning to and implementing single sign-on for, and not just the SCIM endpoint.
trans-unit.target: Note that the application object created is intend to represent the target app you would be provisioning to and implementing single sign-on for, and not just the SCIM endpoint.

trans-unit.source: In the resulting screen, select the second **Configure account provisioning** button.
trans-unit.target: In the resulting screen, select the second **Configure account provisioning** button.

trans-unit.source: In the dialog, enter the internet-exposed URL and port of your SCIM endpoint.
trans-unit.target: In the dialog, enter the internet-exposed URL and port of your SCIM endpoint.

trans-unit.source: This would be something like http://testmachine.contoso.com:9000 or http://<ip-address>:9000/, where <ip-address> is the internet exposed IP address.
trans-unit.target: This would be something like http://testmachine.contoso.com:9000 or http://<ip-address>:9000/, where <ip-address> is the internet exposed IP address.

trans-unit.source: Click **Next**, and click on the **Start Test** button to have Azure Active Directory attempt to connect to the SCIM endpoint.
trans-unit.target: Click **Next**, and click on the **Start Test** button to have Azure Active Directory attempt to connect to the SCIM endpoint.

trans-unit.source: If the attempts fail, diagnostic information will be displayed.
trans-unit.target: If the attempts fail, diagnostic information will be displayed.

trans-unit.source: If the attempts to connect to your Web service succeed, then click **Next** on the remaining screens, and click **Complete** to exit the dialog.
trans-unit.target: If the attempts to connect to your Web service succeed, then click **Next** on the remaining screens, and click **Complete** to exit the dialog.

trans-unit.source: In the resulting screen, select the third **Assign Accounts** button.
trans-unit.target: In the resulting screen, select the third **Assign Accounts** button.

trans-unit.source: In the resulting Users and Groups section, assign the users or groups you want to provision to the application.
trans-unit.target: In the resulting Users and Groups section, assign the users or groups you want to provision to the application.

trans-unit.source: Once users and groups are assigned, click the **Configure** tab near the top of the screen.
trans-unit.target: Once users and groups are assigned, click the **Configure** tab near the top of the screen.

trans-unit.source: Under **Account Provisioning**, confirm that the Status is set to On.
trans-unit.target: Under **Account Provisioning**, confirm that the Status is set to On.

trans-unit.source: Under **Tools**, click **Restart account provisioning** to kick-start the provisioning process.
trans-unit.target: Under **Tools**, click **Restart account provisioning** to kick-start the provisioning process.

trans-unit.source: Note that 5-10 minutes may elapse before the provisioning process will begin to send requests to the SCIM endpoint.
trans-unit.target: Note that 5-10 minutes may elapse before the provisioning process will begin to send requests to the SCIM endpoint.

trans-unit.source: A summary of connection attempts is provided on the application’s Dashboard tab, and both a report of provisioning activity and any provisioning errors can be downloaded from the directory’s Reports tab.
trans-unit.target: A summary of connection attempts is provided on the application’s Dashboard tab, and both a report of provisioning activity and any provisioning errors can be downloaded from the directory’s Reports tab.

trans-unit.source: The final step in verifying the sample is to open the TargetFile.csv file in the \AzureAD-BYOA-Provisioning-Samples\ProvisioningAgent\bin\Debug folder on your Windows machine.
trans-unit.target: The final step in verifying the sample is to open the TargetFile.csv file in the \AzureAD-BYOA-Provisioning-Samples\ProvisioningAgent\bin\Debug folder on your Windows machine.

trans-unit.source: Once the provisioning process is run, this file shows the details of all assigned and provisioned users and groups.
trans-unit.target: Once the provisioning process is run, this file shows the details of all assigned and provisioned users and groups.

trans-unit.source: Development Libraries
trans-unit.target: Development Libraries

trans-unit.source: To develop your own Web service that conforms to the SCIM specification, first familiarize yourself with the following libraries provided by Microsoft to help accelerate the development process:
trans-unit.target: To develop your own Web service that conforms to the SCIM specification, first familiarize yourself with the following libraries provided by Microsoft to help accelerate the development process:

trans-unit.source: **1:** Common Language Infrastructure libraries are offered for use with languages based on that infrastructure, such as C#.
trans-unit.target: **1:** Common Language Infrastructure libraries are offered for use with languages based on that infrastructure, such as C#.

trans-unit.source: One of those libraries, [Microsoft.SystemForCrossDomainIdentityManagement.Service](https://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.SystemForCrossDomainIdentityManagement/), declares an interface, Microsoft.SystemForCrossDomainIdentityManagement.IProvider, shown in the figure below.
trans-unit.target: One of those libraries, [Microsoft.SystemForCrossDomainIdentityManagement.Service](https://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.SystemForCrossDomainIdentityManagement/), declares an interface, Microsoft.SystemForCrossDomainIdentityManagement.IProvider, shown in the figure below.

trans-unit.source: A developer using the libraries would implement that interface with a class that may be referred to, generically, as a provider.
trans-unit.target: A developer using the libraries would implement that interface with a class that may be referred to, generically, as a provider.

trans-unit.source: The libraries enable the developer to easily deploy a Web service that conforms to the SCIM specification, either hosted within Internet Information Services, or any executable Common Language Infrastructure assembly.
trans-unit.target: The libraries enable the developer to easily deploy a Web service that conforms to the SCIM specification, either hosted within Internet Information Services, or any executable Common Language Infrastructure assembly.

trans-unit.source: Requests to that Web service will be translated into calls to the provider’s methods, which would be programmed by the developer to operate on some identity store.
trans-unit.target: Requests to that Web service will be translated into calls to the provider’s methods, which would be programmed by the developer to operate on some identity store.

trans-unit.source: **2:** [Express route handlers](http://expressjs.com/guide/routing.html) are available for parsing node.js request objects representing calls (as defined by the SCIM specification), made to a node.js Web service.
trans-unit.target: **2:** [Express route handlers](http://expressjs.com/guide/routing.html) are available for parsing node.js request objects representing calls (as defined by the SCIM specification), made to a node.js Web service.

trans-unit.source: Building a Custom SCIM Endpoint
trans-unit.target: Building a Custom SCIM Endpoint

trans-unit.source: Using the libraries described above, developers using those libraries can host their services within any executable Common Language Infrastructure assembly, or within Internet Information Services.
trans-unit.target: Using the libraries described above, developers using those libraries can host their services within any executable Common Language Infrastructure assembly, or within Internet Information Services.

trans-unit.source: Here is sample code for hosting a service within an executable assembly, at the address http://localhost:9000:
trans-unit.target: Here is sample code for hosting a service within an executable assembly, at the address http://localhost:9000:

trans-unit.source: It is important to note that this service must have an HTTP address and server authentication certificate of which the root certification authority is one of the following:
trans-unit.target: It is important to note that this service must have an HTTP address and server authentication certificate of which the root certification authority is one of the following:

trans-unit.source: CNNIC
trans-unit.target: CNNIC

trans-unit.source: Comodo
trans-unit.target: Comodo

trans-unit.source: CyberTrust
trans-unit.target: CyberTrust

trans-unit.source: DigiCert
trans-unit.target: DigiCert

trans-unit.source: GeoTrust
trans-unit.target: GeoTrust

trans-unit.source: GlobalSign
trans-unit.target: GlobalSign

trans-unit.source: Go Daddy
trans-unit.target: Go Daddy

trans-unit.source: Verisign
trans-unit.target: Verisign

trans-unit.source: WoSign
trans-unit.target: WoSign

trans-unit.source: A server authentication certificate can be bound to a port on a Windows host using the network shell utility, like so:
trans-unit.target: A server authentication certificate can be bound to a port on a Windows host using the network shell utility, like so:

trans-unit.source: Here, the value provided for the certhash argument is the thumbprint of the certificate, while the value provided for the appid argument is an arbitrary globally-unique identifier.
trans-unit.target: Here, the value provided for the certhash argument is the thumbprint of the certificate, while the value provided for the appid argument is an arbitrary globally-unique identifier.

trans-unit.source: To host the service within Internet Information Services, a developer would build a Common Language Infrastructure code library assembly with a class named Startup in the default namespace of the assembly.
trans-unit.target: To host the service within Internet Information Services, a developer would build a Common Language Infrastructure code library assembly with a class named Startup in the default namespace of the assembly.

trans-unit.source: Here is a sample of such a class:
trans-unit.target: Here is a sample of such a class:

trans-unit.source: Handling Endpoint Authentication
trans-unit.target: Handling Endpoint Authentication

trans-unit.source: Requests from Azure Active Directory include an OAuth 2.0 bearer token.
trans-unit.target: Requests from Azure Active Directory include an OAuth 2.0 bearer token.

trans-unit.source: Any service receiving the request should authenticate the issuer as being Azure Active Directory on behalf of the expected Azure Active Directory tenant, for access to Azure Active Directory’s Graph Web service.
trans-unit.target: Any service receiving the request should authenticate the issuer as being Azure Active Directory on behalf of the expected Azure Active Directory tenant, for access to Azure Active Directory’s Graph Web service.

trans-unit.source: In the token, the issuer is identified by an iss claim, like, "iss":"https://sts.windows.net/cbb1a5ac-f33b-45fa-9bf5-f37db0fed422/".
trans-unit.target: In the token, the issuer is identified by an iss claim, like, "iss":"https://sts.windows.net/cbb1a5ac-f33b-45fa-9bf5-f37db0fed422/".

trans-unit.source: In this example, the base address of the claim value, https://sts.windows.net, identifies Azure Active Directory as the issuer, while the relative address segment, cbb1a5ac-f33b-45fa-9bf5-f37db0fed422, is a unique identifier of the Azure Active Directory tenant on behalf of which the token was issued.
trans-unit.target: In this example, the base address of the claim value, https://sts.windows.net, identifies Azure Active Directory as the issuer, while the relative address segment, cbb1a5ac-f33b-45fa-9bf5-f37db0fed422, is a unique identifier of the Azure Active Directory tenant on behalf of which the token was issued.

trans-unit.source: If the token was issued for accessing the Azure Active Directory’s Graph Web service, then the identifier of that service, 00000002-0000-0000-c000-000000000000, should be in the value of the token’s aud claim.
trans-unit.target: If the token was issued for accessing the Azure Active Directory’s Graph Web service, then the identifier of that service, 00000002-0000-0000-c000-000000000000, should be in the value of the token’s aud claim.

trans-unit.source: Developers using the Common Language Infrastructure libraries provided by Microsoft for building a SCIM service can authenticate requests from Azure Active Directory using the Microsoft.Owin.Security.ActiveDirectory package by following these steps:
trans-unit.target: Developers using the Common Language Infrastructure libraries provided by Microsoft for building a SCIM service can authenticate requests from Azure Active Directory using the Microsoft.Owin.Security.ActiveDirectory package by following these steps:

trans-unit.source: **1:** In a provider, implement the Microsoft.SystemForCrossDomainIdentityManagement.IProvider.StartupBehavior property by having it return a method to be called whenever the service is started:
trans-unit.target: **1:** In a provider, implement the Microsoft.SystemForCrossDomainIdentityManagement.IProvider.StartupBehavior property by having it return a method to be called whenever the service is started:

trans-unit.source: **2:** Add the following code to that method to have any request to any of the service’s endpoints authenticated as bearing a token issued by Azure Active Directory on behalf of a specified tenant, for access to Azure Active Directory’s Graph Web service:
trans-unit.target: **2:** Add the following code to that method to have any request to any of the service’s endpoints authenticated as bearing a token issued by Azure Active Directory on behalf of a specified tenant, for access to Azure Active Directory’s Graph Web service:

trans-unit.source: User and Group Schema
trans-unit.target: User and Group Schema

trans-unit.source: Azure Active Directory can provision two types of resources to SCIM Web Services.
trans-unit.target: Azure Active Directory can provision two types of resources to SCIM Web Services.

trans-unit.source: Those types of resources are users and groups.
trans-unit.target: Those types of resources are users and groups.

trans-unit.source: User resources are identified by the schema identifier, urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:enterprise:2.0:User, which is included in this protocol specification: http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-scim-core-schema.
trans-unit.target: User resources are identified by the schema identifier, urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:enterprise:2.0:User, which is included in this protocol specification: http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-scim-core-schema.

trans-unit.source: The default mapping of the attributes of users in Azure Active Directory to the attributes of urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:enterprise:2.0:User resources is provided in table 1, below.
trans-unit.target: The default mapping of the attributes of users in Azure Active Directory to the attributes of urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:enterprise:2.0:User resources is provided in table 1, below.

trans-unit.source: Group resources are identified by the schema identifier, http://schemas.microsoft.com/2006/11/ResourceManagement/ADSCIM/Group.
trans-unit.target: Group resources are identified by the schema identifier, http://schemas.microsoft.com/2006/11/ResourceManagement/ADSCIM/Group.

trans-unit.source: Table 2, below, shows the default mapping of the attributes of groups in Azure Active Directory to the attributes of http://schemas.microsoft.com/2006/11/ResourceManagement/ADSCIM/Group resources.
trans-unit.target: Table 2, below, shows the default mapping of the attributes of groups in Azure Active Directory to the attributes of http://schemas.microsoft.com/2006/11/ResourceManagement/ADSCIM/Group resources.

trans-unit.source: Table 1: Default user attribute mapping
trans-unit.target: Table 1: Default user attribute mapping

trans-unit.target: urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:enterprise:2.0:User

trans-unit.source: User Provisioning and De-Provisioning
trans-unit.target: User Provisioning and De-Provisioning

trans-unit.source: The figure below shows the messages that Azure Active Directory will send to a SCIM service to manage the lifecycle of a user in another identity store.
trans-unit.target: The figure below shows the messages that Azure Active Directory will send to a SCIM service to manage the lifecycle of a user in another identity store.

trans-unit.source: The diagram also shows how a SCIM service implemented using the Common Language Infrastructure libraries provided by Microsoft for building such services will translate those requests into calls to the methods of a provider.
trans-unit.target: The diagram also shows how a SCIM service implemented using the Common Language Infrastructure libraries provided by Microsoft for building such services will translate those requests into calls to the methods of a provider.

trans-unit.source: Figure: User provisioning and de-provisioning sequence
trans-unit.target: Figure: User provisioning and de-provisioning sequence

trans-unit.source: **1:** Azure Active Directory will query the service for a user with an externalId attribute value matching the mailNickname attribute value of a user in Azure Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: **1:** Azure Active Directory will query the service for a user with an externalId attribute value matching the mailNickname attribute value of a user in Azure Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: The query will be expressed as a Hypertext Transfer Protocol request like this one, wherein jyoung is a sample of a mailNickname of a user in Azure Active Directory:
trans-unit.target: The query will be expressed as a Hypertext Transfer Protocol request like this one, wherein jyoung is a sample of a mailNickname of a user in Azure Active Directory:

trans-unit.source: If the service was built using the Common Language Infrastructure libraries provided by Microsoft for implementing SCIM services, then the request will be translated into a call to the Query method of the service’s provider.
trans-unit.target: If the service was built using the Common Language Infrastructure libraries provided by Microsoft for implementing SCIM services, then the request will be translated into a call to the Query method of the service’s provider.

trans-unit.source: Here is the signature of that method:
trans-unit.target: Here is the signature of that method:

trans-unit.source: Here is the definition of the Microsoft.SystemForCrossDomainIdentityManagement.IQueryParameters interface:
trans-unit.target: Here is the definition of the Microsoft.SystemForCrossDomainIdentityManagement.IQueryParameters interface:

trans-unit.source: In the case of the foregoing sample of a query for a user with a given value for the externalId attribute, values of the arguments passed to the Query method will be as follows:
trans-unit.target: In the case of the foregoing sample of a query for a user with a given value for the externalId attribute, values of the arguments passed to the Query method will be as follows:

trans-unit.source: parameters.AlternateFilters.Count: 1
trans-unit.target: parameters.AlternateFilters.Count: 1

trans-unit.source: parameters.AlternateFilters.ElementAt(0).AttributePath: "externalId"
trans-unit.target: parameters.AlternateFilters.ElementAt(0).AttributePath: "externalId"

trans-unit.source: parameters.AlternateFilters.ElementAt(0).ComparisonOperator: ComparisonOperator.Equals
trans-unit.target: parameters.AlternateFilters.ElementAt(0).ComparisonOperator: ComparisonOperator.Equals

trans-unit.source: parameters.AlternateFilter.ElementAt(0).ComparisonValue: "jyoung"
trans-unit.target: parameters.AlternateFilter.ElementAt(0).ComparisonValue: "jyoung"

trans-unit.source: correlationIdentifier: System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage.GetOwinEnvironment["owin.RequestId"]
trans-unit.target: correlationIdentifier: System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage.GetOwinEnvironment["owin.RequestId"]

trans-unit.source: **2:** If the response to a query to the service for a user with an externalId attribute value matching the mailNickname attribute value of a user in Azure Active Directory does not return any users, then Azure Active Directory will request that the service provision a user corresponding to the one in Azure Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: **2:** If the response to a query to the service for a user with an externalId attribute value matching the mailNickname attribute value of a user in Azure Active Directory does not return any users, then Azure Active Directory will request that the service provision a user corresponding to the one in Azure Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: Here is an example of such a request:
trans-unit.target: Here is an example of such a request:

trans-unit.source: The Common Language Infrastructure libraries provided by Microsoft for implementing SCIM services would translate that request into a call to the Create method of the service’s provider.
trans-unit.target: The Common Language Infrastructure libraries provided by Microsoft for implementing SCIM services would translate that request into a call to the Create method of the service’s provider.

trans-unit.source: The Create method has this signature:
trans-unit.target: The Create method has this signature:

trans-unit.source: In the case of a request to provision a user, the value of the resource argument will be an instance of the Microsoft.SystemForCrossDomainIdentityManagement.
trans-unit.target: In the case of a request to provision a user, the value of the resource argument will be an instance of the Microsoft.SystemForCrossDomainIdentityManagement.

trans-unit.source: Core2EnterpriseUser class, defined in the Microsoft.SystemForCrossDomainIdentityManagement.Schemas library.
trans-unit.target: Core2EnterpriseUser class, defined in the Microsoft.SystemForCrossDomainIdentityManagement.Schemas library.

trans-unit.source: If the request to provision the user succeeds, then the implementation of the method is expected to return an instance of the the Microsoft.SystemForCrossDomainIdentityManagement.
trans-unit.target: If the request to provision the user succeeds, then the implementation of the method is expected to return an instance of the the Microsoft.SystemForCrossDomainIdentityManagement.

trans-unit.source: Core2EnterpriseUser class, with the value of the Identifier property set to the unique identifier of the newly-provisioned user.
trans-unit.target: Core2EnterpriseUser class, with the value of the Identifier property set to the unique identifier of the newly-provisioned user.

trans-unit.source: **3:** To update a user known to exist in an identity store fronted by an SCIM, Azure Active Directory will proceed by requesting the current state of that user from the service with a request like this one:
trans-unit.target: **3:** To update a user known to exist in an identity store fronted by an SCIM, Azure Active Directory will proceed by requesting the current state of that user from the service with a request like this one:

trans-unit.source: In a service built using the Common Language Infrastructure libraries provided by Microsoft for implementing SCIM services, the request will be translated into a call to the Retrieve method of the service’s provider.
trans-unit.target: In a service built using the Common Language Infrastructure libraries provided by Microsoft for implementing SCIM services, the request will be translated into a call to the Retrieve method of the service’s provider.

trans-unit.source: Here is the signature of the Retrieve method:
trans-unit.target: Here is the signature of the Retrieve method:

trans-unit.source: In the case of the foregoing example of a request to retrieve the current state of a user, the values of the properties of the object provided as the value of the parameters argument will be as follows:
trans-unit.target: In the case of the foregoing example of a request to retrieve the current state of a user, the values of the properties of the object provided as the value of the parameters argument will be as follows:

trans-unit.source: SchemaIdentifier: "urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:enterprise:2.0:User"
trans-unit.target: SchemaIdentifier: "urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:enterprise:2.0:User"

trans-unit.source: **4:** If a reference attribute is to be updated, then Azure Active Directory will query the service to determine whether or not the current value of the reference attribute in the identity store fronted by the service already matches the value of that attribute in Azure Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: **4:** If a reference attribute is to be updated, then Azure Active Directory will query the service to determine whether or not the current value of the reference attribute in the identity store fronted by the service already matches the value of that attribute in Azure Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: In the case of users, the only attribute of which the current value will be queried in this way is the manager attribute.
trans-unit.target: In the case of users, the only attribute of which the current value will be queried in this way is the manager attribute.

trans-unit.source: Here is an example of a request to determine whether the manager attribute of a particular user object currently has a certain value:
trans-unit.target: Here is an example of a request to determine whether the manager attribute of a particular user object currently has a certain value:

trans-unit.source: The value of the attributes query parameter, id, signifies that if a user object exists that satisfies the expression provided as the value of the filter query parameter, then the service is expected to respond with a urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:core:2.0:User or urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:enterprise:2.0:User resource, including only the value of that resource’s id attribute.
trans-unit.target: The value of the attributes query parameter, id, signifies that if a user object exists that satisfies the expression provided as the value of the filter query parameter, then the service is expected to respond with a urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:core:2.0:User or urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:enterprise:2.0:User resource, including only the value of that resource’s id attribute.

trans-unit.source: Of course, the value of the id attribute is known to the requestor—it is included in the value of the filter query parameter; the purpose of asking for it is actually to request a minimal representation of a resource that satisfying the filter expression as an indication of whether or not any such object exists.
trans-unit.target: Of course, the value of the id attribute is known to the requestor—it is included in the value of the filter query parameter; the purpose of asking for it is actually to request a minimal representation of a resource that satisfying the filter expression as an indication of whether or not any such object exists.

trans-unit.source: If the service was built using the Common Language Infrastructure libraries provided by Microsoft for implementing SCIM services, then the request will be translated into a call to the Query method of the service’s provider.
trans-unit.target: If the service was built using the Common Language Infrastructure libraries provided by Microsoft for implementing SCIM services, then the request will be translated into a call to the Query method of the service’s provider.

trans-unit.source: The value of the properties of the object provided as the value of the parameters argument will be as follows:
trans-unit.target: The value of the properties of the object provided as the value of the parameters argument will be as follows:

trans-unit.source: parameters.AlternateFilters.Count: 2
trans-unit.target: parameters.AlternateFilters.Count: 2

trans-unit.source: parameters.AlternateFilters.ElementAt(x).AttributePath: "id"
trans-unit.target: parameters.AlternateFilters.ElementAt(x).AttributePath: "id"

trans-unit.source: parameters.AlternateFilters.ElementAt(x).ComparisonOperator: ComparisonOperator.Equals
trans-unit.target: parameters.AlternateFilters.ElementAt(x).ComparisonOperator: ComparisonOperator.Equals

trans-unit.source: parameters.AlternateFilter.ElementAt(x).ComparisonValue: "54D382A4-2050-4C03-94D1-E769F1D15682"
trans-unit.target: parameters.AlternateFilter.ElementAt(x).ComparisonValue: "54D382A4-2050-4C03-94D1-E769F1D15682"

trans-unit.source: parameters.AlternateFilters.ElementAt(y).AttributePath: "manager"
trans-unit.target: parameters.AlternateFilters.ElementAt(y).AttributePath: "manager"

trans-unit.source: parameters.AlternateFilters.ElementAt(y).ComparisonOperator: ComparisonOperator.Equals
trans-unit.target: parameters.AlternateFilters.ElementAt(y).ComparisonOperator: ComparisonOperator.Equals

trans-unit.source: parameters.AlternateFilter.ElementAt(y).ComparisonValue: "2819c223-7f76-453a-919d-413861904646"
trans-unit.target: parameters.AlternateFilter.ElementAt(y).ComparisonValue: "2819c223-7f76-453a-919d-413861904646"

trans-unit.source: parameters.RequestedAttributePaths.ElementAt(0): "id"
trans-unit.target: parameters.RequestedAttributePaths.ElementAt(0): "id"

trans-unit.source: parameters.SchemaIdentifier: "urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:enterprise:2.0:User"
trans-unit.target: parameters.SchemaIdentifier: "urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:enterprise:2.0:User"

trans-unit.source: Here, the value of the index x may be 0 and the value of the index y may be 1, or the value of x may be 1 and the value of y may be 0, depending on the order of the expressions of the filter query parameter.
trans-unit.target: Here, the value of the index x may be 0 and the value of the index y may be 1, or the value of x may be 1 and the value of y may be 0, depending on the order of the expressions of the filter query parameter.

trans-unit.source: Group Provisioning and De-Provisioning
trans-unit.target: Group Provisioning and De-Provisioning

trans-unit.source: The figure below shows the messages that Azure Active Directory will send to a SCIM service to manage the lifecycle of a group in another identity store.
trans-unit.target: The figure below shows the messages that Azure Active Directory will send to a SCIM service to manage the lifecycle of a group in another identity store.

trans-unit.source: Those messages differ from the messages pertaining to users in three ways:
trans-unit.target: Those messages differ from the messages pertaining to users in three ways:

trans-unit.source: The schema of a group resource will be identified as http://schemas.microsoft.com/2006/11/ResourceManagement/ADSCIM/Group.
trans-unit.target: The schema of a group resource will be identified as http://schemas.microsoft.com/2006/11/ResourceManagement/ADSCIM/Group.

trans-unit.source: Requests to retrieve groups will stipulate that the members attribute is to be excluded from any resource provided in response to the request.
trans-unit.target: Requests to retrieve groups will stipulate that the members attribute is to be excluded from any resource provided in response to the request.

trans-unit.source: Requests to determine whether a reference attribute has a certain value will be requests about the members attribute.
trans-unit.target: Requests to determine whether a reference attribute has a certain value will be requests about the members attribute.

trans-unit.source: Figure: Group provisioning and de-provisioning sequence
trans-unit.target: Figure: Group provisioning and de-provisioning sequence
